title: Problem Overview
content: This module formalizes **Erdős Problem #1108**: Two OPEN questions about finite sums of distinct factorials and their relationship to perfect powers and powerful numbers.
mathContext: Asked by Erdős at Oberwolfach in 1988, motivated by discussions with Mahler. Brindza-Erdős (1991) proved a partial result for fixed number of terms.

title: Factorial Sums Set
content: **FactorialSums** is the set A = {m : exists finite S, m = sum of n! for n in S}. This includes 0, 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 24, etc.
mathContext: Like binary representation uses powers of 2, we can represent some numbers as sums of distinct factorials. The rapid growth of n! makes this set sparse for large numbers.

title: Factorial Sum Examples
content: We prove concrete membership: 0 (empty sum), 1 = 0!, 2 = 2!, 6 = 3!, 24 = 4! are all factorial sums.

title: Powerful Numbers
content: **IsPowerful n** means every prime p dividing n satisfies p^2 | n. Equivalently, all prime exponents are >= 2.
mathContext: Powerful numbers are products of squares and cubes: 1, 4, 8, 9, 16, 25, 27, 32, 36, 49, 64, 72, ... They are relatively rare among integers.

title: 1 is Powerful
content: **one_is_powerful**: 1 is vacuously powerful since no prime divides 1.
mathContext: The proof uses Nat.eq_one_of_dvd_one: if p | 1 then p = 1, but primes are > 1, contradiction.

title: Main Question Sets
content: **KthPowersInFactorialSums k** = factorial sums that are k-th powers. **PowerfulFactorialSums** = factorial sums that are powerful.
mathContext: The main questions ask whether these sets are finite. If KthPowersInFactorialSums(2) is finite, there are only finitely many perfect squares expressible as factorial sums.

title: Question 1 (OPEN)
content: **erdos_1108_kth_powers_open**: For each k >= 2, does FactorialSums contain only finitely many k-th powers? This is axiomatized as a Prop since the answer is unknown.
mathContext: Even the case k=2 (squares) is open. It's not known if there are infinitely many squares expressible as sums of distinct factorials.

title: Question 2 (OPEN)
content: **erdos_1108_powerful_open**: Does FactorialSums contain only finitely many powerful numbers? Also axiomatized as an unknown Prop.
mathContext: Powerful numbers are rarer than perfect powers, so this might be easier, but it's still open.

title: Brindza-Erdős Bound (1991)
content: **brindza_erdos_bound**: For fixed r terms, if n1! + ... + nr! is powerful, then n1 <= C(r). The largest index is bounded.
mathContext: This is a partial result: for any fixed r, only finitely many r-term factorial sums can be powerful. But r is unbounded in the main question.

title: Mahler's Related Problem
content: Mahler asked about sums of powers of k. For k <= 4, infinitely many squares exist. For k >= 5, only one known: 1+7+49+343 = 400 = 20^2.
mathContext: Mahler discussed this with Erdős shortly before his death in 1988, inspiring Problem #1108. The factorial version sits between these cases in some sense.

title: Summary Theorem
content: **erdos_1108_summary** packages verified results: 1 is both a square factorial sum and powerful, and Mahler's example 1+7+49+343=400.
mathContext: This shows the sets KthPowersInFactorialSums(2) and PowerfulFactorialSums are nonempty. The question is whether they're finite.
